title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_param function allows define parametric survival model specified distribution parameter values. Parameterization based flexsurv package.
code: param_surv <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   print(param_surv) #> A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3).

what: Defining a Parametric Mixture/Non-Mixture Cure Model
title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_cure function allows define parametric mixture/non-mixture cure model specified distribution, cure fraction, parameter values.
code: cure_surv <- define_surv_cure('exp', theta = 0.21, rate = 0.04, mixture = TRUE)   print(cure_surv) #> An exponential mixture cure distribution (theta = 0.21, rate = 0.04).

what: Defining a Royston & Parmar Spline Model
title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_spline function allows define Royston & Parmar restricted cubic spline model specified scale, parameter values, knot times.
code: spline_dist <- define_surv_spline(     scale = 'hazard', # spline used to model log cumulative hazards     -2.08, 2.75, 0.23, # parameters     -1.62, 0.57, 1.191 # knot times   )   print(spline_dist) #> A Royston & Parmar spline model of log cumulative hazard with 3 knots (gamma = [-2.08, 2.75, 0.23], knots = [-1.62, 0.57, 1.19]).

what: Defining a Survival Distribution from Kaplan-Meier Output
title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_km function allows define survival distribution based times survival probabilities Kaplan-Meier.
code: km_output <- data.frame(     times = c(0, 2, 5, 10, 17, 21),     surv_prob = c(1, 0.98, 0.94, 0.89, 0.78, 0.78)   )   km_dist <- define_surv_km(km_output, "times", "surv_prob")   print(km_dist) #> A Kaplan-Meier distribution: #>    time survival #>   <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1     0     1    #> 2     2     0.98 #> 3     5     0.94 #> 4    10     0.89 #> 5    17     0.78 #> 6    21     0.78

what: Defining a Survival Distribution from a Life-Table
title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_lifetable function allows define survival distribution based life-table, starting age, gender mix.
code: life_table <- data.frame(     age_in_years = c(50, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55),     p_death_male = c(0.0021, 0.0022, 0.0022, 0.0023, 0.0022, 0.0024),     p_death_female = c(0.0018, 0.0018, 0.0018, 0.0019, 0.0019, 0.0020)   )   lifetable_dist <- define_surv_lifetable(     life_table, # data.frame containing life-table     51, # starting age     0.48, # percent male     age_col = 'age_in_years', # column in life-table containing age     male_col = 'p_death_male', # column in life-table containing male p(death)     female_col = 'p_death_female' # column in life-table containing female p(death)   )   print(lifetable_dist) #> A life-table survival distribution (48.0% male, 52.0% female): #>     age   male female #>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1    51 0.0022 0.0018 #> 2    52 0.0022 0.0018 #> 3    53 0.0023 0.0019 #> 4    54 0.0022 0.0019 #> 5    55 0.0024 0.002

what: Defining a Survival Distributions from a Custom Function
title: Defining Survival Distributions
text: define_surv_func function allows define survival distribution based custom function.
code: custom_dist <- define_surv_func(function(t) pweibull(t, 1.2, 20.1, lower.tail = FALSE))   print(custom_dist) #> A survival distribution based on a custom function: function(t) pweibull(t, 1.2, 20.1, lower.tail = FALSE)

title: Generating Predictions
text: Predicted survival probabilities can generated given survival distribution set times using surv_prob function.

title: Generating Predictions
text: Event probabilities can generated given survival distributon set time intervals using event_prob function.

title: Getting Started
text: herosurv package contains number functions defining survival distributions various types. example, define_surv_param function allows define parametric survival distribution given family given parameter values. information kinds survival distributions supported herosurv can found “Defining Survival Distributions” vignette.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)

title: Getting Started
text: Printing herosurv survival distribution provide description contents.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('exp', rate = 0.013)   print(dist1) #> An exponential distribution (rate = 0.013).

title: Getting Started
text: Survival probabilities can generated distribution using surv_prob function.

title: Getting Started
text: Survival probabilities distribution can graphed using plot method.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   plot(dist1, max_time = 20)

title: Getting Started
text: Survival distributions can modified using variety functions provided herosurv. example, apply_hr function can used apply hazard ratio survival distribution. also possible combine multiple survival distributions one. example, join function allows two survival distributions joined specified cutpoint.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- apply_hr(dist1, 0.45)   print(dist2) #> A proportional hazards survival distribution: #>     * Hazard Ratio: 0.45 #>     * Baseline Distribution: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3). dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1)   dist3 <- join(dist1, 3, dist2) # Join dist2 and dist3 at time 3   print(dist3) #> A joined survival distribution: #>     * Segment 1 (t = 0 - 3): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3). #>     * Segment 2 (t = 3 - ∞): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1).

title: Getting Started
text: complicated survival distributions can created stringing together multiple herosurv operations. Use %>% operator magrittr supported.
code: # create an exponential distribution   dist1 <- define_surv_param('exp', rate = 0.04)      # create a survival distribution based on custom function   dist2 <- define_surv_func(function(t) pweibull(t, 1.2, 20.1, lower.tail = FALSE))    # create a Royston & Parmar spline model   dist3 <- define_surv_spline(     scale = 'hazard', # spline used to model log cumulative hazards     -2.08, 2.75, 0.23, # parameters     -1.62, 0.57, 1.191   )    dist4 <- dist1 %>% # take dist1       apply_hr(0.4) %>% # apply a hazard ratio of 0.4 to it       join(4, dist2) %>% # join it to dist2 at time 4       mix(0.25, dist3, 0.75) # mix the result with dist4 with weights of 25% and 75% respectively    print(dist4) #> A mixed survival distribution: #>     * Distribution 1 (25%):  #>         A joined survival distribution: #>             * Segment 1 (t = 0 - 4):  #>                 A proportional hazards survival distribution: #>                     * Hazard Ratio: 0.4 #>                     * Baseline Distribution: An exponential distribution (rate = 0.04). #>             * Segment 2 (t = 4 - ∞): A survival distribution based on a custom function: function(t) pweibull(t, 1.2, 20.1, lower.tail = FALSE) #>     * Distribution 2 (75%): A Royston & Parmar spline model of log cumulative hazard with 3 knots (gamma = [-2.08, 2.75, 0.23], knots = [-1.62, 0.57, 1.19]).

title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Hazard ratios can applied survival distribution using apply_hr function.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- apply_hr(dist1, 0.85)   print(dist2) #> A proportional hazards survival distribution: #>     * Hazard Ratio: 0.85 #>     * Baseline Distribution: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3).

title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Odds ratios can applied survival distribution using apply_or function.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- apply_or(dist1, 0.45)   print(dist2) #> A proportional odds survival distribution: #>     * Odds Ratio: 0.45 #>     * Baseline Distribution: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3).

title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Accleration factors, proportionally scale event times, can applied using apply_af function.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- apply_af(dist1, 0.75)   print(dist2) #> An accelerated failure time survival distribution: #>     * Acceleration Factor: 0.75 #>     * Baseline Distribution: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3).

title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Hazards distribution can shifted forward backward fixed amount time using apply_shift function. Note positive value shift move hazards forward negative value shift hazards backward (resulting initial period event risk).
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- apply_shift(dist1, 2.1)   print(dist2) #> A shifted survival distribution: #>     * Shift: 2.1 #>     * Baseline Distribution: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3).

what: Mixing Distributions Accordingy to Specified Weights
title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Survival distributions can mixed according specified weights using mix function.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1)   dist3 <- mix(dist1, 0.8, dist2, 0.2) # Mix of 80% dist1 and 20% dist2   print(dist3) #> A mixed survival distribution: #>     * Distribution 1 (80%): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3). #>     * Distribution 2 (20%): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1).

what: Joining Two or More Distributions at Specified Cutpoints
title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Survival distributions can joined together specified cutpoints using join function.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1)   dist3 <- join(dist1, 3, dist2) # Join dist2 and dist3 at time 3   print(dist3) #> A joined survival distribution: #>     * Segment 1 (t = 0 - 3): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3). #>     * Segment 2 (t = 3 - ∞): A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1).

what: Combining Two or More Distributions as Indepedent Risks
title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Survival distributions can combined independent risks using add_hazards function. results survival distribution survival function equal product survival functions combined distributions.
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3)   dist2 <- define_surv_param('weibull', shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1)   dist3 <- add_hazards(dist1, dist2) # combined hazards of dist1 and dist2   print(dist3) #> A survival distribution combining the hazards of: #>     * Distribution 1: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.2, scale = 5.3). #>     * Distribution 2: A Weibull (AFT) distribution (shape = 1.4, scale = 4.1).

what: Setting Covariates For Model with Predictors
title: Modifying & Combining Distributions
text: Models fitted using survfit flexsurvreg predictors can used generate survival distribution representing subject set subjects using set_covariates.
code: library(flexsurv) #> Loading required package: survival library(tibble)  # Fit a model using bc dataset using good as predictor print(as_tibble(bc)) #> # A tibble: 686 × 4 #>    censrec rectime group recyrs #>      <int>   <int> <fct>  <dbl> #>  1       0    1342 Good    3.68 #>  2       0    1578 Good    4.32 #>  3       0    1760 Good    4.82 #>  4       0    1152 Good    3.16 #>  5       0     967 Good    2.65 #>  6       0     629 Good    1.72 #>  7       0     461 Good    1.26 #>  8       1     991 Good    2.72 #>  9       0     758 Good    2.08 #> 10       0    1617 Good    4.43 #> # … with 676 more rows fs1 <- flexsurvreg(Surv(recyrs, censrec)~group, data = bc, dist = 'weibull')  # Survival distribution representing patient w/ group = "Good" good_model <- set_covariates(fs1, data.frame(group = 'Good')) print(good_model) #> Predicted survival from fitted model for specified cohort: #>     * Cohort:  #>           group #>           <chr> #>         1 Good  #>     * Model:  #>         Call: #>         flexsurvreg(formula = Surv(recyrs, censrec) ~ group, data = bc,  #>             dist = "weibull") #>          #>         Estimates:  #>                      data mean  est      L95%     U95%     se       exp(est)  L95%    #>         shape             NA     1.3797   1.2548   1.5170   0.0668       NA        NA #>         scale             NA    11.4229   9.1818  14.2110   1.2728       NA        NA #>         groupMedium   0.3338    -0.6136  -0.8623  -0.3649   0.1269   0.5414    0.4222 #>         groupPoor     0.3324    -1.2122  -1.4583  -0.9661   0.1256   0.2975    0.2326 #>                      U95%    #>         shape             NA #>         scale             NA #>         groupMedium   0.6943 #>         groupPoor     0.3806 #>          #>         N = 686,  Events: 299,  Censored: 387 #>         Total time at risk: 2113.425 #>         Log-likelihood = -811.9419, df = 4 #>         AIC = 1631.884 #>   # Survival distribution with patient representing cohort w/ # equal mix of group = "Good" and group = "Poor" good_and_poor_model <- set_covariates(fs1, data.frame(group = c('Good', 'Poor'))) print(good_and_poor_model) #> Predicted survival from fitted model for specified cohort: #>     * Cohort:  #>           group #>           <chr> #>         1 Good  #>         2 Poor  #>     * Model:  #>         Call: #>         flexsurvreg(formula = Surv(recyrs, censrec) ~ group, data = bc,  #>             dist = "weibull") #>          #>         Estimates:  #>                      data mean  est      L95%     U95%     se       exp(est)  L95%    #>         shape             NA     1.3797   1.2548   1.5170   0.0668       NA        NA #>         scale             NA    11.4229   9.1818  14.2110   1.2728       NA        NA #>         groupMedium   0.3338    -0.6136  -0.8623  -0.3649   0.1269   0.5414    0.4222 #>         groupPoor     0.3324    -1.2122  -1.4583  -0.9661   0.1256   0.2975    0.2326 #>                      U95%    #>         shape             NA #>         scale             NA #>         groupMedium   0.6943 #>         groupPoor     0.3806 #>          #>         N = 686,  Events: 299,  Censored: 387 #>         Total time at risk: 2113.425 #>         Log-likelihood = -811.9419, df = 4 #>         AIC = 1631.884 #>

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jordan Amdahl. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Amdahl J (2021). herosurv: Grammar Survival Operations CE Models. https://github.com/PolicyAnalysisInc/herosurv, http://www.heroapps.io/herosurv, https://policyanalysisinc.github.io/herosurv.
code: @Manual{,   title = {herosurv: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models},   author = {Jordan Amdahl},   year = {2021},   note = {https://github.com/PolicyAnalysisInc/herosurv, http://www.heroapps.io/herosurv, https://policyanalysisinc.github.io/herosurv}, }

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
text: herosurv grammar survival modeling use health economic modeling. provides series verbs help define, combine, modify survival distributions.

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
code: # Install latest version from github install_github("PolicyAnalysisInc/herosurv")

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
text: Parametric distributions specified parameter values: define_surv_param() Parametric mixture & non-mixture cure models specified parameter values: define_surv_cure() Royston & Parmar spline models specified parameter values: define_surv_spline() Life-tables: define_surv_lifetable() Kaplan-Meiers based product-limit table: define_surv_km() Custom Functions: define_surv_func() Full support models estimated using flexsurv package Partial support KMs & Cox Models estimated using survival package

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
text: Apply hazard ratio: apply_hr() Apply odds ratio: apply_or() Apply acceleration factor: apply_af() Apply shift time: apply_shift() Set covariate levels models covariates: set_covariates()

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
text: Join survival distributions together specified times: join() Mix together survival distributions specified weights: mix() Combine distributions independent risks: add_hazards()

title: A Grammar of Survival Operations for CE Models
text: Generate survival probabilities: surv_prob() Generate event probabilities: event_prob()

title: herosurv
text: herosurv grammar survival modeling use health economic modeling. provides series verbs help define, combine, modify survival distributions.

title: herosurv
code: # Install latest version from github install_github("PolicyAnalysisInc/herosurv")

title: herosurv
text: Parametric distributions specified parameter values: define_surv_param() Parametric mixture & non-mixture cure models specified parameter values: define_surv_cure() Royston & Parmar spline models specified parameter values: define_surv_spline() Life-tables: define_surv_lifetable() Kaplan-Meiers based product-limit table: define_surv_km() Custom Functions: define_surv_func() Full support models estimated using flexsurv package Partial support KMs & Cox Models estimated using survival package

title: herosurv
text: Apply hazard ratio: apply_hr() Apply odds ratio: apply_or() Apply acceleration factor: apply_af() Apply shift time: apply_shift() Set covariate levels models covariates: set_covariates()

title: herosurv
text: Join survival distributions together specified times: join() Mix together survival distributions specified weights: mix() Combine distributions independent risks: add_hazards()

title: herosurv
text: Generate survival probabilities: surv_prob() Generate event probabilities: event_prob()

title: Add Hazards — add_hazards
text: Combine two survival distributions independent risks adding hazards.

title: Add Hazards — add_hazards
code: add_hazards(dist1, dist2, ...)

title: Add Hazards — add_hazards
text: dist1 survival distribution add dist2 second survival distribution add ... additional survival distributions add

title: Add Hazards — add_hazards
text: surv_add_haz object

title: Add Hazards — add_hazards
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param("exp", rate = .125) dist2 <- define_surv_param("weibull", shape = 1.2, scale = 50) combined_dist <- add_hazards(dist1, dist2)

title: Apply Acceleration Factor — apply_af
text: Apply acceleration factor proportionally increase reduce time--event survival distribution.

title: Apply Acceleration Factor — apply_af
code: apply_af(dist, af, log_af = FALSE)

title: Apply Acceleration Factor — apply_af
text: dist survival distribution af acceleration factor applied survival distribution log_af optional argument (defaults FALSE) indicate provided acceleration factor log scale

title: Apply Acceleration Factor — apply_af
text: surv_aft object.

title: Apply Acceleration Factor — apply_af
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param("exp", rate = 0.25) aft_dist <- apply_af(dist1, 1.5)

title: Apply Hazard Ratio — apply_hr
text: Apply hazard ratio distribution proportionally reduce increase hazard rate.

title: Apply Hazard Ratio — apply_hr
code: apply_hr(dist, hr, log_hr = FALSE)

title: Apply Hazard Ratio — apply_hr
text: dist survival distribution hr hazard ratio applied survival distribution log_hr optional argument (defaults FALSE) indicate provided hazard ratio log scale

title: Apply Hazard Ratio — apply_hr
text: surv_ph object.

title: Apply Hazard Ratio — apply_hr
code: ph_dist <- apply_hr(  define_surv_param("exp", rate = 0.25),  0.5 )

title: Apply Odds Ratio — apply_or
text: Apply odds ratio proportionally increase reduce odds survival

title: Apply Odds Ratio — apply_or
code: apply_or(dist, or, log_or = FALSE)

title: Apply Odds Ratio — apply_or
text: dist survival distribution odds ratio applied survival distribution log_or optional argument (defaults FALSE) indicate provided odds ratio log scale

title: Apply Odds Ratio — apply_or
text: surv_po object.

title: Apply Odds Ratio — apply_or
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param("exp", rate = 0.25) po_dist <- apply_or(dist1, 1.12)

what: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
title: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
text: Apply fixed shift time move hazards survival distribution forwards backwards.

title: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
code: apply_shift(dist, shift)

title: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
text: dist survival distribution shift amount time shift distribution, positive value moves hazards forward negative value delays hazards.

title: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
text: surv_shift object.

title: Apply Fixed Shift in Time — apply_shift
code: shifted_dist <- apply_shift(  define_surv_param("exp", rate = 0.25),  3 )

what: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
text: Define parametric mixture mixture cure distribution given parameter values.

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
code: define_surv_cure(distribution, theta, ..., mixture = TRUE)  define_survival_cure(distribution, theta, ..., mixture = TRUE)

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
text: distribution parametric survival distribution. See details listing valid distributions. theta numeric value representing cure fraction ... Additional distribution parameters (see details section ) mixture logical determining whether mixture non-mixture model defined.

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
text: surv_dist_cure object.

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
text: Supported distributions listed table .

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
text: Stacy, E. W. (1962). generalization gamma distribution.  Annals Mathematical Statistics 33:1187-92. Prentice, R. L. (1974). log gamma model maximum likelihood estimation. Biometrika 61(3):539-544. R. L. Prentice (1975). Discrimination among parametric models. Biometrika 62(3):607-614.

title: Define Parametric Mixture or Non-Mixture Cure Distribution — define_surv_cure
code: define_surv_cure(distribution = "exp", theta = 0.34, rate = .5) #> An exponential mixture cure distribution (theta = 0.34, rate = 0.50). define_surv_cure(  distribution = "weibull",  theta = 0.5, shape = 1.5,  scale = 34.43,  mixture = TRUE ) #> A Weibull (AFT) mixture cure distribution (theta = 0.5, shape = 1.5, scale = 34.4). # Deprecated alias included for backwards compatability with heRomod define_survival_cure(distribution = "exp", theta = 0.24, rate = 0.023) #> An exponential mixture cure distribution (theta = 0.240, rate = 0.023).

what: Define survival distribution based on a function — define_surv_func
title: Define survival distribution based on a function — define_surv_func
text: Define survival distribution based function

title: Define survival distribution based on a function — define_surv_func
code: define_surv_func(f, ...)

title: Define survival distribution based on a function — define_surv_func
text: f function takes vector times returns vector corresponding survival probabilities ... additional arguments passed f

title: Define survival distribution based on a function — define_surv_func
text: surv_function object.

title: Define Kaplan-Meier Distribution — define_surv_km
text: Define survival distribution based table Kaplan-Meier output containing times survival probabilities.

title: Define Kaplan-Meier Distribution — define_surv_km
code: define_surv_km(x, time_col = "time", surv_col = "survival")  define_surv_table(x, time_col = "time", surv_col = "survival")

title: Define Kaplan-Meier Distribution — define_surv_km
text: x data frame columns time survival probability. default, columns assumed named time survival, can configured via optional parameters. time_col name time column (defaults time) surv_col name time column (defaults survival)

title: Define Kaplan-Meier Distribution — define_surv_km
text: surv_km object.

title: Define Kaplan-Meier Distribution — define_surv_km
code: df <- data.frame(      time = c(0, 1, 5, 10),      survival = c(1, 0.9, 0.7, 0.5) ) define_surv_km(df) #> A Kaplan-Meier distribution: #>    time survival #>   <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1     0      1   #> 2     1      0.9 #> 3     5      0.7 #> 4    10      0.5

title: Define Life-Table Distribution — define_surv_lifetable
text: Define survival distribution based life-table containing mortality rates age gender.

title: Define Life-Table Distribution — define_surv_lifetable
code: define_surv_lifetable(   x,   start_age,   percent_male,   output_unit = "years",   age_col = "age",   male_col = "male",   female_col = "female",   dpy = get_dpy(),   percent_female = NULL )

title: Define Life-Table Distribution — define_surv_lifetable
text: x data frame columns starting age age band, conditional probability death age men, conditional probability death women. Default column names "age", "male", "female", can set via optional arguments. start_age starting age population. percent_male percent population male. Calculated 1 - percent_female provided. output_unit optional arguemnt time unit resulting survival distribution defined terms . Valid options c("days", "weeks", "months", "years"). Defaults "years". age_col optional argument change name age column accepted first argument. male_col optional argument change name male column accepted first argument. female_col optional argument change name female column accepted first argument. dpy optional argument specifying number days per year used time unit conversion. argument populated automatically heromod model. percent_female percent population female. Calculated 1 - percent_male provided.

title: Define Life-Table Distribution — define_surv_lifetable
text: surv_lifetable object.

title: Define Life-Table Distribution — define_surv_lifetable
code: x <- data.frame(      age = c(0, 1, 2, 3),      male = c(0.011, 0.005, 0.003, 0.002),      female = c(0.010, 0.005, 0.004, 0.002)  )  define_surv_lifetable(x, 1, 0.45) #> A life-table survival distribution (45.0% male, 55.0% female): #>     age  male female #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1     1 0.005  0.005 #> 2     2 0.003  0.004 #> 3     3 0.002  0.002

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
text: Define parametric survival distribution given parameter values. complete listing supported distributions provided details section.

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
code: define_surv_param(distribution, ...)  define_survival(distribution, ...)

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
text: distribution parametric survival distribution. ... additional distribution parameters (see details section )

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
text: surv_parametric object.

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
text: Supported distributions listed table .

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
text: Stacy, E. W. (1962). generalization gamma distribution.  Annals Mathematical Statistics 33:1187-92. Prentice, R. L. (1974). log gamma model maximum likelihood estimation. Biometrika 61(3):539-544. R. L. Prentice (1975). Discrimination among parametric models. Biometrika 62(3):607-614.

title: Define Parametric Distribution — define_surv_param
code: define_surv_param(distribution = "exp", rate = .5) #> An exponential distribution (rate = 0.5). define_surv_param(distribution = "gompertz", rate = .5, shape = 1) #> A Gompertz distribution (shape = 1.0, rate = 0.5).  # Deprecated alias included for backwards compatability with heRomod define_survival(distribution = "exp", rate = 0.05) #> An exponential distribution (rate = 0.05).

what: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
text: Define Royston & Parmar restricted cubic spline parametric survival distribution.

title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
code: define_surv_spline(scale, ...)  define_spline_survival(scale, ...)

title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
text: scale "hazard", "odds", "normal", described flexsurvspline. default knots addition boundaries, models reduce Weibull, log-logistic log-normal respectively. scale must common times. ... parameters knot log times spline distribution, can provided either order starting spline parameters followed knot log times, names (e.g gamma1, gamma2, ... gammaN, knots1, knots2, ... knotsN). See examples named unnamed calls.

title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
text: surv_spline object.

title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
text: Royston, P. Parmar, M. (2002).  Flexible parametric proportional-hazards proportional-odds models censored survival data, application prognostic modelling estimation treatment effects. Statistics Medicine 21(1):2175-2197.

title: Define Royston & Parmar Spline Survival Distribution — define_surv_spline
code: define_surv_spline(  scale = 'hazard',  -2.08, 2.75, 0.23, # parameters  -1.62, 0.57, 1.191 # knot times ) #> A Royston & Parmar spline model of log cumulative hazard with 3 knots (gamma = [-2.08, 2.75, 0.23], knots = [-1.62, 0.57, 1.19]).

title: Evaluate Event Probabilities — event_prob
text: Generate conditional probability even interval time.

title: Evaluate Event Probabilities — event_prob
code: event_prob(x, start, end, ...)

title: Evaluate Event Probabilities — event_prob
text: x surv_dist object start numeric vector interval start times end numeric vector interval end times ... additional arguments passed methods

title: Extract Product-Limit Tables — extract_strata
text: Extracts product-limit table survfit object strata. survfit unstratified survfit.coxph objects supported.

title: Extract Product-Limit Tables — extract_strata
code: extract_strata(sf)

title: Extract Product-Limit Tables — extract_strata
text: sf survit object.

title: Extract Product-Limit Tables — extract_strata
text: tidy data.frame product-limit tables strata.

what: Extract Product-Limit Table for Stratum — extract_stratum
title: Extract Product-Limit Table for Stratum — extract_stratum
text: Extracts product-limit table survfit object given stratum. survival::survfit() unstratified survival::survfit.coxph() objects supported.

title: Extract Product-Limit Table for Stratum — extract_stratum
code: extract_stratum(sf, index)

title: Extract Product-Limit Table for Stratum — extract_stratum
text: sf survit object. index index number strata extract.

title: Extract Product-Limit Table for Stratum — extract_stratum
text: data frame product-limit table given stratum.

title: Join Distributions — join
text: Join two distributions together specified cut points.

title: Join Distributions — join
code: join(dist1, cut1, dist2, ...)

title: Join Distributions — join
text: dist1 survival distribution use time 0 cut cut1 cut point dist1 dist2 dist2 survival distribution use cut ... Additional cutpoints distributions

title: Join Distributions — join
text: surv_join object

title: Join Distributions — join
code: dist1 <- define_survival(distribution = "exp", rate = 0.05) dist2 <- define_survival(distribution = "gompertz", rate = .5, shape = 1) dist3 <- define_survival(distribution = "exp", rate = 0.25) join_dist <- join(dist1, 20, dist2) join_dist2 <- join(dist1, 20, dist2, 50, dist3)

what: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
title: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
text: Mix set survival distributions using specified weights.

title: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
code: mix(dist1, weight1, dist2, weight2, ...)

title: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
text: dist1 first survival distribution mix weight1 probability weight first distribution dist2 second survival distribution mix weight2 probability weight second distribution ... additional distributions weights

title: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
text: surv_mix object.

title: Mix Two or More Survival Distributions — mix
code: dist1 <- define_surv_param("exp", rate = .5) dist2 <- define_surv_param("gompertz", rate = .5, shape = 1) pooled_dist <- mix(dist1, 0.25, dist2, 0.75)

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
title: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
text: Generate survival distribution representing model predictions specified cohort. cohort can defined providing data frame covariate values (multiple subjects) providing covariate values named arguments (single subject).

title: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
code: set_covariates(dist, data, ...)

title: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
text: dist survfit flexsurvreg object data data.frame representing subjets predictions generated ... optional argument representing covariate values generate predictions , can used instead data argument

title: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
text: surv_model object

title: Set Covariates of a Survival Model — set_covariates
code: library(flexsurv) #> Loading required package: survival fs1 <- flexsurvreg(   Surv(rectime, censrec)~group,   data=flexsurv::bc,   dist = "llogis" ) good_model <- set_covariates(fs1, group = "Good") cohort <- data.frame(group=c("Good", "Good", "Medium", "Poor")) mixed_model <- set_covariates(fs1, data = cohort)

title: Evaluate Survival Probabilities — surv_prob
text: Generate survival probabilities survival distribution specified times.

title: Evaluate Survival Probabilities — surv_prob
code: surv_prob(x, time, ...)  eval_surv(x, time, ...)  compute_surv(x, time, cycle_length = 1, type = "prob", ...)

title: Evaluate Survival Probabilities — surv_prob
text: x surv_dist object time numeric vector times ... additional arguments passed methods

title: Evaluate Survival Probabilities — surv_prob
text: numeric vector survival probabilities
